channel.title: Tetris [C++/OpenGL/Cross-platform]
channel.description:
I stayed up literally all night doing this, starting at 6pm last night and going to sleep at 8am this morning only to wake back up again at 10am to go to class.
I have pre-compiled binaries for a variety of systems, most likely yours, but source is provided of course if you want to compile it yourself.
One small note on windows compilation, apparently there is not a cross platform way to sleep, in linux I used my own Sleep() function with a wait time of 50000, in windows simply include windows.h, comment out my sleep function, and change the wait time to 50. This only affects the animation when a row is dropped. If someone knows a better way to sleep, please let me know.
I am on campus right now, so I can only provide a win32 screenshot:
[img]http://img219.imageshack.us/img219/9555/tetrisqu5.jpg[/img]
win32: http://www.moparisthebest.com/projects/tetriswin32.exe linux32: http://www.moparisthebest.com/projects/tetrislnx32 linux64: http://www.moparisthebest.com/projects/tetrislnx64
project with project description and make file: http://www.moparisthebest.com/projects/tetris.tar.gz
only the source (.h and .cpp) files: http://www.moparisthebest.com/projects/tetrissrc.zip
Have fun, and try to leave some feedback, especially about sleeping.

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;


int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
	#ifdef WIN32
	cout << "WIN32 defined" << endl;
	#endif
	#ifdef _WINDOWS
	cout << "_WINDOWS defined" << endl;
	#endif
	#ifdef _WINDOWS_
	cout << "_WINDOWS_ defined" << endl;
	#endif
	cout << "this prints every time" << endl;
	return 0;
}

output:

WIN32 defined
this prints every time

In visual studio, I will report the results with gcc and mingw when I get home.

item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

seand:

[quote author=lawl link=topic=200592.msg1784623#msg1784623 date=1190941691]err, why, if WIN32 is defined for you?

WIN32 isn’t defined as exactly that for every compiler, so it’s easier on the programmer to just make his own[/quote]

WIN32 isn’t, but _WIN32 is guaranteed to be defined for you if you’re on a 32 bit system running windows, and WINDOWS or _WINDOWS is guaranteed to be defined if you’re on windows in general.
